children.subject:
Am I allowed to P/NP?

I would rather not say which class it is. It's just a CS upper div.
If it is CS 189 please consider sending me or the other TAs an email. I am willing to help you personally if it's for this class.
The only reason I'm posting is because I am supremely confident I can't do it. I just can't - I wish I never tried.
Have you tried those things? I was seriously a mess until I started going to OH every day.

Go and talk to the professor privately. In every course I have taught, there have been occasions when students would need to talk to me privately because they felt that they couldn't do it. Sometimes this is true and sometimes it is not. Mostly, it is not true. But through an interactive conversation with the professor, you can get much more than you can by ruminating about it yourself. Because they've seen many many students go through the material while you have only seen yourself, and that too not very clearly.
Go to all the office hours you possibly can. Find a group you can meet with consistently. That's how I survived. You can do it, but it's very difficult to do alone!
I would love more details about this new policy if possible. Do you have any links to the policy? Why do you think I might still be able to drop?
The policy I'm referring to is the "green petition" mentioned by Lydia.

If you're in CoE, there has recently been a policy change allowing late drops under certain circumstances. I won't describe it exactly but go make an appointment with your ESS advisor- you might be able to drop it still!

history.content:
I'm sorry that you're having such a hard time this semester. As the students have referenced below, you will need to speak with your ESS advisor. You could have three options, but again your ESS advisor would know for sure.

Option 1) Since you will complete your degree requirements this semester without this class, check with your ESS advisor if you should submit this petition to change the grade to P/NP after the deadline due to circumstance A. Documentation is required so it would be a good idea to visit the Tang Center or Dr. Christine Zhou in 241 Bechtel, christinez@uhs.berkeley.edu or (510) 643-7850. I think her drop-in hours are Tues and Wed. or

Option 2) Submit this petition to drop the course after the deadline due to circumstance A. Documentation is required so it would be a good idea to visit the Tang Center or Dr. Christine Zhou in 241 Bechtel, christinez@uhs.berkeley.edu or (510) 643-7850. I think her drop-in hours are Tues and Wed, or

Option 3) Ask your ESS advisor about the green petition, the new policy that allows students to drop a class after the deadline one time. Information about this petition is not available online.

children.subject: I think it depends...you should talk to your ESS adviser about your needs and they can figure out whether the green petition makes sense for you or not.
Does the green petition only allow you to drop classes, or can you also change to P/NP with them as well?

history.content:
I'm a junior EECS student taking an upper-div EECS class that is not required for graduation. I personally find that the difficulty of the material has markedly increased. This has been sucking up all of my time as of late, causing me insane amounts of stress, and has hurt my mental health.

Every day it becomes more clear that I simply can't keep up with the class I'm currently taking. The stress is literally consuming every minute of my life. Is there any way at all to drop the class? I just feel an impending sense of doom now. It is clear to me that I won't be able to improve no matter how hard I try or how much help I try to get.

Edit: Could someone tell me how the new policy in the follow-up to @2554 relates? If I'll have completed 45 technical units (20 upper-div) by the end of this semester, will I be able to P/NP this upper-div course?
history.subject: Incredible amounts of stress from taking a class
